official-title.#text: To define STEM education to include computer science, and to support existing STEM education programs at the National Science Foundation.

attestation-date.#text: Passed the House of Representatives July 14, 2014.

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Institute of Standards and Technology

quote.#tail: means education in the subjects of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, including other academic subjects that build on these disciplines such as computer science.

text.#text: For purposes of carrying out STEM education activities at the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the National Science Foundation

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , shall continue to award competitive, merit-reviewed grants to support—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Directorate for Education and Human Resources
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Directorate for Education and Human Resources

text.#text: research and development of innovative out-of-school STEM learning and emerging STEM learning environments in order to improve STEM learning outcomes and engagement in STEM; and
research that advances the field of informal STEM education.
Activities supported by grants under this section may encompass a single STEM discipline, multiple STEM disciplines, or integrative STEM initiatives and shall include—
research and development that improves our understanding of learning and engagement in informal environments, including the role of informal environments in broadening participation in STEM; and

design and testing of innovative STEM learning models, programs, and other resources for informal learning environments to improve STEM learning outcomes and increase engagement for K–12 students, K–12 teachers, and the general public, including design and testing of the scalability of models, programs, and other resources.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 10A of the National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002

quote.#text: for teachers with master’s degrees in their field

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002/s:10A/ss:c/p:3/sp:B

text.#text: by striking the period at the end of
by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: Master Teaching Fellowships for teachers with bachelor’s degrees in their field and working toward a master’s degree—

text.#text: offering academic courses leading to a master’s degree and leadership training to prepare individuals to become master teachers in elementary and secondary schools; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and to exchange ideas with others in their fields.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002/s:10A/s:e

text.#text: offering programs both during and after matriculation in the program for which the fellowship is received to enable fellows to become highly effective mathematics and science teachers, including mentoring, training, induction, and professional development activities, to fulfill the service requirements of this section, including the requirements of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: Master Teacher Fellow may receive a maximum of 1 year of fellowship support while enrolled in a master’s degree program as described in
, except that if such fellow is enrolled in a part-time program, such amount shall be prorated according to the length of the program.
